Woolly Mammoth: I would choose to bring back the Woolly Mammoth because it is one of the most iconic and fascinating extinct animals. Its sheer size and unique appearance would make it a spectacle to behold. Moreover, it would be interesting to see how it would adapt to the modern world.

Tasmanian Tiger: The Tasmanian Tiger was a marsupial that was native to Australia and Tasmania. It had a distinctive orange and black striped coat and was known for its ferocity. Bringing it back to life would be an exciting challenge, and we could study its behavior and habits to better understand its extinction.

Dodo: The Dodo was a flightless bird that lived on the island of Mauritius. It was known for its distinctive appearance and lack of fear, making it an easy target for predators. Bringing it back to life would be a great opportunity to study its behavior and adaptations in a safe environment.

Saber-Toothed Tiger: The Saber-Toothed Tiger was a large prehistoric cat that lived in North and South America. It had long, curved claws and teeth that were used for hunting prey. Bringing it back to life would be a thrilling experience, and we could study its hunting techniques and social behavior.

Giant Panda: The Giant Panda was a bear-like mammal that lived in China. It was known for its distinctive black and white fur and was a symbol of China's national animal. Bringing it back to life would be an exciting opportunity to study its behavior and adaptations in a natural habitat, and we could also learn more about its diet and habitat requirements.
